results.title: Peach's Australia : Mount Buffalo
results.creator_credit: Lloyd Capps and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Peach’s Australia”.
It is the position of Mt Buffalo, standing apart from the Victorian Alps, and its extraordinary shape, that have led it to being called Australia’s grandest, wildest, most novel and most romantic mountain.

results.title: Peach's Australia : Hahndorf
results.creator_credit: Bill Steller, Alan Bateman and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Peach’s Australia”.
Traces the history of the town of Hahndorf, South Australia, beginning with the German settlers who arrived at Port Misery (Port Adelaide) in 1838. Outlines their reasons for leaving Germany, the establishment of Klemzig, the movement of some Germans into the Adelaide Hills and the difficulties they encountered. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Peach's Australia : Chinatown: Dixon Street
results.creator_credit: Christopher McCullough and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Peach’s Australia”.
Anti-Chinese riots on the goldfields caused many Chinese to shift to the cities of Sydney and Melbourne. Chinatowns sprung up and became the centres of their business and social life, cultural and racial ghettos, where the people lived and worked together for mutual help and protection. The film looks at Sydney’s Dixon Street where, over half a century ago, two-thirds of Sydney’s Chinese population lived.

results.title: Solo basic
results.creator_credit: Bill Mason, Bill Brind and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Path of the Paddle”.
The joy and poetry of paddling solo are illustrated in this film, as are all the basic strokes used in maintaining complete control of the canoe. With the aid of animated lines, the path of the paddle is clearly defined so there can be no mistaking what the paddle is doing. The use of the various strokes in rapids is demonstrated sufficiently to whet the appetite to move on.

results.title: Doubles basic
results.creator_credit: Bill Mason, Colin Low, Bill Brind and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Path of the Paddle”.
Paddling double, the canoeists demonstrate the basic paddling strokes and how to apply them in a variety of combinations to move the canoe at will. Throughout the film the application of each stroke in rapids is shown briefly, with emphasis on the necessity of working as a well-coordinated team.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bill Mason, Colin Low, Bill Brind and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Solo whitewater
results.creator_credit: Bill Mason, Bill Brind and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Path of the Paddle”.
This film explains clearly how to locate a deep water channel by reading the rapids and how to apply the many paddling strokes and manoeuvres to steer the canoe where you want it to go. It also depicts what happens if you make a mistake and “wipe out” in a turbulent rapid, and how to survive the swim. (Award: Venissieux.)

results.title: Doubles whitewater
results.creator_credit: Bill Mason, Colin Low, Bill Brind and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Path of the Paddle”.
Running rapids will always be a calculated risk. But risk diminishes with skill and knowledge. In this film, two canoeists paddling double demonstrate how to read the rapids, plan a course and follow it in complete control of the boat, using the basic paddling strokes. The strokes can be used in endless combination to reduce the risk of whitewater canoeing and increase the sheer joy and exuberance of a whitewater run.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bill Mason, Colin Low, Bill Brind and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Part time parent, full time job
results.creator_credit: Eurfron Gwynne Jones, Dick Foster and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Parents and Children”.
Society expects parents to be both workers and up-bringers. Two societies have made conscious attempts to resolve the conflict between the world of work and the family - Sweden and the Israeli Kibbutz.
